physDesc.p: Three pages typewritten in black ink. Mrs. Richard Aldington 44 Mechlenburgh Square London, W.C. England is the typed address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am sending two money orders, one for $25.48 for you and Richard, and one for Lawrence’s share which is $12.74, plus this little gift of $200.00. Here is the account: SALES 26 Imagist Poets, 1915 at .36-1/4 $ 9.43 43 Imagist Poets, 1916 at .36-1/4 15.59 142 Imagist Poets, 1917 at .38-1/4 51.47 $ 76.49 $76.49 divided by 6 - $12.74 – 2.14.0 I am also writing a letter to Lawrence in care of you.

Do you know Richard is the only one of my three English Imagists who took the trouble to answer my requests for a biography. This makes the writing for Flint and Lawrence very difficult. The body of Flint’s work is so extremely slight that it will be hard to give him enough space when I have nothing to say about him personally. As to Lawrence, I suppose he has been much too worried and upset to think anything about it. But I think it is unfortunate.
Do you know, Hilda, the more I read Richard’s work, the more deeply I admire it, and, by the same token, the more I read Flint’s and Lawrence’s the less I like them.

Richard wrote me a charming letter the other day and said that he was sending me the manuscript of his poems and would I look after it. You may certainly rely on me to do my best. I am having a perfectly fearful time here with Brown. I do not think that Brown means to be dishonest, but he is very unbusinesslike, and he bites off more than he can chew. The result is that he is in a constant mess financially, and as Richard never gave me that power of attorney, I have no real hold over him. Just now I have been trying my best to get a number of copies of Richard’s "Images" to send with the poetry libraries I am sending to the thirty-four training camps in this country. He says he has sheets of "Images," but they are not yet bound, and he keeps promising them for next week, and they never come, and I do not think they ever will come. He has had the manuscript of Fletcher’s Japanese Poems for a year and a half, and has not published it yet. I am afraid if he takes this manuscript of Richard’s, he will just hold on to it and not publish it. He has moved into new and rather splendid quarters, and I imagine has done so by borrowing the money and therefore has no ready cash. I have asked him to send me an accounting of the sales of Richard’s books so that I may see if the fifteen dollars already paid covers the royalties due. I do not suppose it shall even be able to get the accounting out of him for a long time, however.

I do, therefore, sincerely advise not having him print Richard’s new book. The only trouble with that is the more businesslike publishers have got dreadfully cold feet about publishing poetry just now. They do not want to spend any money on it, and they are all cutting down. Still, Ferris Greenslet has asked to see the manuscript, but I have no real hope there, nor have I with Macmillan, although I shall sound Mr. Brett on the subject when I go to New York next week. There is a possibility that Mr. Harcourt of Holt’s might be induced to take it. At any rate, I shall try all these people before ceding the manuscript to Brown, but if Richard should have changed his mind and sent the manuscript direct to Brown (for I have not yet received it) the matter ill be more difficult. In a way I do not blame Brown, for I know he is struggling very hard against dreadful odds. I do blame him for his eternal lying, however. He seems to think that it would be bad policy to say that he is stuck for the moment, whereas I think every one would respect him more, and the good will of his business would be saved if he told the truth.
I will let you know after I have been to New York what the outlook is, and I do hope that Richard’s manuscript will come in time for me to take it with me.

I am sorry to say that your "Sea Garden" is out of print over here, and Houghton-Mifflin tell me that it is so difficult to import anything that they are not going to import any more sheets. If you can send me thirty-three copies, I can send them after the libraries which have already gone out to be included in them. I cannot bear to have your work not represented, but I took the very last copy that Houghton-Mifflin had.

I am up to my eyes in work, not only on my Brooklyn lectures, but on some poems of my own. I have been doing a long series called "Phantasms of War" for "The Independent," and I also have some polyphonic, semi-historical things that Macmillan is very anxious to print in a book next Autumn, if I can get enough done. I have them all mapped out, but they take a long time to write, and I am rather discouraged at the way time fleets away. I think I shall gather my miscellaneous essays and lectures into a volume of prose a year from now, in which case my present appreciation of Richard will have a permanent form.
